content.description:
Spartahug climbs a lowball overhang on perfect stone over a decent landing.

Sit start with hands matched on the hueco's undercling. From there, reach a three-finger right hand pinch, then cross over by falling into a positive crimp at the lip, and work the remaining bumps up and right with a heel hook for the finish.
content.protection: A pad or two or three. The immediate fall zone is great, but there is a tree and a some rocks that line the outskirts of the landing.
content.location: It climbs the center of Midland's east face.

content.description: Stand start with hands matched on the horizontal edge about five feet off the ground. From there, work the edges while smearing the highly oxidized slab for an easy topout.
content.protection: Not a great landing, as a rock sits directly below the problem. A pad or two should work fine though, as the problem doesn't climb very high.
content.location: This is on the south-facing slab on Midland Rock.

content.description: Stand start with hands on opposing, incut sidepulls. From there, work straight up using the high quality patina edges and top it out through the tree branches.
content.protection: A pad should suffice, it has a nice landing. There is, however, a tree next to the landing.
content.location: This is on the south face of Midland Rock.

content.description: Sit start with hands matched on the large shelf.  From there, make a large, right hand deadpoint or dyno to the lip, match with the left, then reach a sharp crimp with the left high on the slab, throw a right heel, and mantle over (crux) for the topout.
content.protection: A few pads wouldn't hurt, it's a lowball, but there are a few rocks in the landing.
content.location: This ascends the center east face of Midland Rock.

content.description: Stand start with a left hand gaston and a right sidepull at the arete. From there, move up and match hands on the shelf, then gain a pair of two or three finger pockets, lock a heel, hit a bump out left, then top it out (crux).
content.protection: A few pads should do it, there are some nasty rocks out left of the problem, but the immediate landing is very good.
content.location: It ascends the northeast arete of Midland Rock.

content.description: This climbs easy pockets, edges, and flakes on the far right side of the south face.
content.location:
This is the path of least resistance on the far right end of the south face, about 5' left of

Nincompoop

.

content.description:
Sit start with a left hand sidepull, a right hand on the shelf, and a left foot edge.  From there, fire a right hand to the lip (crux), then work the bumps, throw a right heel onto the lip, and pull over with a mantle.

The beginning feet are thin and low to the ground, this makes the first move tricky and difficult to avoid dabbing.
content.protection: A few pads should do, the landing is good, but there is a rock on one side of the problem.
content.location: It ascends the overhanging east side of the southeast arete on Midland Rock.
